story.title: If and If-Else: Making Choices
story.backgroundSetup: The Code Garden, a magical classroom where programming concepts bloom like flowers. The room features floating code panels that display examples, decision trees that grow from the ground, and pathways that split into two directions based on conditions. The walls are covered in glowing binary symbols (true/false, yes/no) that pulse with the rhythm of logical thinking. Professor Ildar teaches here, using whimsical demonstrations where students follow different paths based on simple conditions.
story.description: A whimsical introduction to if statements and if-else statements

characters.name: Professor Ildar
characters.description: A wise, patient professor with a beard that flows like cascading code blocks. He wears a robe covered in question marks and exclamation points that glow when he explains conditions. His spectacles are shaped like parentheses, and he carries a magical pointer that draws glowing paths in the air. His hat is a stack of nested if-statements, and his expression is always encouraging and thoughtful. He moves with deliberate, measured steps, pausing at decision points to let students think.

characters.name: Student Eager Noodler
characters.description: A small, round student with a head shaped like a perfectly smooth, bright green apple, from which two long, springy antennae sprout, constantly twitching with curiosity. They wear an oversized, striped scarf that wraps around them multiple times, ending in a tassel that bounces as they nod vigorously. Their eyes are wide and perpetually amazed, and they often have a tiny, wobbly pencil clutched in a three-fingered hand, ready to scribble notes.

characters.name: student Thoughtful Giggler
characters.description: A tall, lanky student with a head that's a stack of three wobbly, different-sized spheres, each a different shade of blue. They have enormous, floppy ears that droop when they're confused and perk up when they understand. Their smile is wide and stretches almost ear to ear, and they often emit soft, bubbling giggles as they ponder concepts. They wear pants that are far too short, revealing long, segmented legs that end in enormous, flat feet.

characters.name: Student Zippy Zapper
characters.description: A vibrant, energetic student whose body is a series of interconnected, brightly colored zig-zags, always in motion. Their hair is a burst of spiky yellow and orange, standing straight up as if charged with static. They have four small, quick-moving arms, each ending in a suction cup, and their large, round eyes dart around, taking everything in. They have no discernible mouth but communicate through a series of enthusiastic 'boings' and 'zings'

characters.name: Student Quiet observer
characters.description: A shy, somewhat squarish student with a soft, fuzzy purple body and tiny, barely visible legs. Their head is a perfect cube, and instead of eyes, they have two large, circular lenses that slowly adjust, observing everything with intense focus. They carry a small, portable periscope that they often peer through, even in class. They rarely speak, but when they do, it's in a gentle, melodious hum, and they often sketch intricate diagrams in a tiny notebook.

elements.name: Code Garden Classroom
elements.description: A whimsical classroom where code panels float in the air like leaves. The floor has pathways that split into two directions at decision points, marked with glowing true/false signs. Decision trees grow from the ground, their branches representing different code paths. The walls display examples of code that students can touch to see them execute. Floating question marks drift through the air, representing conditions waiting to be evaluated.

elements.name: Decision Pathway
elements.description: A magical pathway that splits into two directions at a decision point. One path glows green (true) and leads to one outcome, the other glows red (false) and leads to another. Students can walk down these paths to experience how if-else statements work. The paths sometimes merge back together after the decision.

elements.name: Condition Evaluator
elements.description: A whimsical machine shaped like a giant question mark that evaluates conditions. When a student presents a condition, it lights up either green (true) or red (false), and then points to the appropriate path or code block. It makes cheerful beeping sounds when evaluating.

elements.name: Code Display Board
elements.description: A large, floating board that displays code examples. The code is written in glowing, colorful letters that students can read easily. When Professor Ildar explains a concept, the relevant parts of the code highlight and pulse. The board can show multiple code examples side by side.

scenes.title: Welcome to Decisions
scenes.description: Professor Ildar stands at the front of the Code Garden Classroom, welcoming the students. Behind him, a large Code Display Board shows a simple if statement. The students are gathered around, looking curious and excited. Decision Pathways are visible in the background, waiting to be explored. The Condition Evaluator sits to the side, glowing softly.
scenes.textPanel:
Welcome, students, to the Code Garden grand,
Where decisions grow like trees across the land!
Today we'll learn to make choices in code,
With if and if-else, a powerful mode!

scenes.title: Simple If Statement
scenes.description: Professor Ildar points to the Code Display Board showing a simple if statement. He demonstrates by checking if it's raining - the Condition Evaluator lights up green (true), and a student walks down the green Decision Pathway holding an umbrella. The other students watch, understanding that when the condition is true, the code inside the if block runs.
scenes.textPanel:
An if statement checks a condition true,
If it's true, then the code will run through!
Like checking if it's raining outside,
If true, grab an umbrella and run to hide!

diagramPanel.content:
is_raining = True

if is_raining:
    print('Grab an umbrella!')
    # Student Eager Noodler grabs their umbrella

scenes.title: When Condition is False
scenes.description: Professor Ildar shows what happens when the condition is false. The Condition Evaluator lights up red (false), and nothing happens - no student walks down any path. The students look confused, and Professor Ildar smiles, explaining that sometimes we need an alternative path. The Code Display Board shows the same if statement, but this time with isRaining set to false.
scenes.textPanel:
But what if the condition is false, you see?
Then nothing happens, as plain as can be!
The code inside the if block won't run,
It's skipped entirely, we're done!

diagramPanel.content:
is_raining = False

if is_raining:
    print('Grab an umbrella!')
    # Student Eager Noodler would grab umbrella
# Nothing happens when False!
# Student Quiet observer notes: condition was False

scenes.title: Introducing If-Else
scenes.description: Professor Ildar introduces the if-else statement. The Code Display Board now shows an if-else structure. He demonstrates with the rain example again - when true, a student takes the green path with an umbrella, when false, a different student takes the red path without an umbrella. The Decision Pathway clearly shows both branches splitting from the same point.
scenes.textPanel:
Now if-else gives us two paths to choose,
One for true, one for false - we can't lose!
If raining is true, grab that umbrella,
Else go outside, be a happy fella!

diagramPanel.content:
is_raining = True

if is_raining:
    print('Grab an umbrella!')
    # Student Eager Noodler grabs umbrella
else:
    print('Go outside and play!')
    # Student Zippy Zapper runs outside excitedly

scenes.title: Comparing Numbers
scenes.description: Professor Ildar shows a practical example comparing numbers. The Code Display Board shows an if-else statement checking if a number is greater than 10. Student Eager Noodler holds up the number 15, and the Condition Evaluator lights up green. Student Thoughtful Giggler holds up the number 5, and it lights up red. Each student follows their respective path.
scenes.textPanel:
We can compare numbers, big and small,
If greater than ten, stand up tall!
Else if it's smaller, sit down low,
The condition decides which way to go!

diagramPanel.content:
number = 15  # Student Eager Noodler's number

if number > 10:
    print('Number is greater than 10!')
    # Student Eager Noodler stands up tall!
else:
    print('Number is 10 or less!')
    # student Thoughtful Giggler sits down low

scenes.title: Checking Equality
scenes.description: Professor Ildar demonstrates checking if two values are equal. The Code Display Board shows an if-else statement using the equality operator (===). Student Zippy Zapper holds up two identical cards, and the Condition Evaluator lights up green. Then Student Quiet observer holds up two different cards, and it lights up red. The students understand that === checks if values match exactly.
scenes.textPanel:
We check if values match, equal and same,
With three equals signs, that's the name!
If they're equal, the first path we take,
Else the other path, for goodness sake!

diagramPanel.content:
password = 'secret123'
user_input = 'secret123'  # Student Zippy Zapper's input

if password == user_input:
    print('Access granted!')
    # Student Zippy Zapper's cards match - green light!
else:
    print('Wrong password!')
    # Student Quiet observer's cards don't match - red light

scenes.title: Multiple Conditions
scenes.description: Professor Ildar shows how to combine conditions using logical operators. The Code Display Board shows an if statement with AND (&&) and OR (||) operators. He demonstrates checking if someone is both old enough AND has permission, or if it's either weekend OR holiday. Students walk down different Decision Pathways based on the combined conditions. The Condition Evaluator evaluates each part separately, then combines the results.
scenes.textPanel:
We can combine conditions, two or more,
With AND and OR, we open the door!
If this AND that, both must be true,
If this OR that, either will do!

diagramPanel.content:
age = 16  # Student Eager Noodler's age
has_permission = True

if age >= 13 and has_permission:
    print('You can watch the movie!')
    # Both conditions True - Student Eager Noodler can go!
else:
    print('Sorry, not allowed!')
    # One or both False - not allowed

# OR example
is_weekend = False
is_holiday = True  # student Thoughtful Giggler checks calendar

if is_weekend or is_holiday:
    print('No school today!')
    # Either True - Student Zippy Zapper celebrates!

scenes.title: Putting It All Together
scenes.description: Professor Ildar stands with all the students gathered around. The Code Display Board shows a complete example combining everything they've learned - multiple if-else statements checking different conditions. All the students are following different Decision Pathways based on their own conditions, demonstrating that each person's code can take different paths. The scene shows the power and flexibility of if-else statements. Professor Ildar smiles proudly as the students understand how to make their programs make decisions.
scenes.textPanel:
Now you know how to make choices in code,
With if and if-else, you're on the right road!
Check conditions, compare values too,
Your programs will know just what to do!

Remember: if true, take one path,
Else take the other, do the math!
Decisions in code make programs smart,
Now you've learned this important art!

diagramPanel.content:
temperature = 75  # Professor Ildar checks the weather
is_sunny = True
has_umbrella = False  # Student Eager Noodler forgot theirs

if temperature > 70 and is_sunny:
    print('Perfect day for the beach!')
    # Student Zippy Zapper zooms to the beach!
elif temperature < 50:
    print('Stay inside, it's cold!')
    # Student Quiet observer stays warm inside
elif is_sunny and has_umbrella:
    print('Nice day, but bring umbrella!')
    # student Thoughtful Giggler prepares carefully
else:
    print('Check the weather first!')
    # Professor Ildar advises checking conditions
